bestBHT.bht: Faithful is the saying that if we be dead with Him, we shall also live with Him. This maxim, possibly part of a Church hymn or accepted formula, underscores the need to die with Christ to partake in His life and glory. It both exhorts and comforts believers, encouraging them to endure trials with the hope of future glory. This faithful saying affirms that we shall live with Christ, supported by His sanctifying presence, and ready to sacrifice for Him.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: If we be dead with Him, we shall also live with Him.

The symmetrical form of 'the saying,' and the rhythmical balance of the parallel clauses, makes it likely, they formed part of a Church hymn or accepted formula, perhaps first uttered by some of the Christian 'prophets' in the public assembly.
Albert Barnes: It is a faithful saying - Or, rather, that which he was about to say was worthy of entire credence and profound attention; see the notes at 1 Timothy 1:15. The object is to encourage Timothy to bear trials by the hope of salvation.
For if we be dead with him - see the notes at Romans 6:8.
We shall also live with him - This was a sort of maxim, or a settled point, which is often referred to in the Bible; see the Romans 6:3-5 notes; John 11:25 note; 1 Thessalonians 4:14 note.
Marvin Vincent: Faithful is the saying that the elect shall obtain salvation with eternal glory."
For the verb, comp. Mark 14:31; 2 Corinthians 7:3.
John Calvin: If we die with him, we shall also live with him...we shall not be partakers of the life and glory of Christ, unless we have previously died and been humbled with him.
This is said both for exhorting and comforting believers...we ought not to be distressed on account of our afflictions, which shall have so happy a result.
By his example, therefore, Paul encourages all believers to receive joyfully, for the name of Christ, those afflictions in which they already have a taste of future glory.
Archibald T. Robertson: For we died with Him, we shall live with Him, we shall reign with Him."
We endure, we are faithless, He cannot deny Himself."
Note the compounds with συν (συναπεθανομεν, we died with, συνζησομεν, we shall live with, συμβασιλευσομεν, we shall reign with).
John Gill: It is a faithful saying,.... to be believed, and depended on as such.
For if we be dead with him... they died with him; being crucified with him.
we shall also live with him... they live a life of sanctification... supported by him...
John Wesley: Dead with him — Dead to sin, and ready to die for him.

This maxim, potentially originating from a Church hymn or accepted formula, emphasizes the importance of our identification with Christ in His death.
